steps.title: “Fasho” (fah-show) is short for “for sure,” which means “yes.”
steps.content: “Fasho” (fah-show) is short for “for sure,” which means “yes.” “Fasho” is a combination, or portmanteau, of the words “for sure.” It’s a popular English slang term used to mean “yes,” “certainly,” “I agree,” or, “That sounds good to me.” It also often appears as “fo’ sho,” “fa-sho,” or, rarely, “4sho” or “foshizzle.” Person 1: “Hey, can I come by your house later?” Person 2: “Yeah, fasho! Just let me clean up a little.”

steps.title: Use “fasho” to casually agree with something someone said.
steps.content: Use “fasho” to casually agree with something someone said. When having a conversation online or in-person, say “for sure” or “fasho” to show agreement with someone else’s statements or opinions. It’s extremely casual and informal, so it’s best to use it among friends. Person 1: “I don’t really like this song.” Person 2: “Fasho, the beat is pretty bland.”

steps.title: Use “fasho” to give confirmation, or to mean “definitely.”
steps.content: Use “fasho” to give confirmation, or to mean “definitely.” “Fasho” is also used to reply in the affirmative to a suggestion, or to make it clear that you understand what someone else is saying. It can also mean that you agree that you’ll do something that another person asks of you. [2] X Research source Person 1: “Will you be at home tonight? I want to watch that new movie.” Person 2: “Fasho, let’s see it!”

steps.title: Say “fasho” to show how excited you are, or to emphasize something.
steps.content: Say “fasho” to show how excited you are, or to emphasize something. Most loosely, “fasho” can simply be used to emphasize a statement or to express your own excitement, willingness, conviction, or enthusiasm for or about something. Example: “This party is fasho going to be wild.” Example: “I’m pumped to see you tonight, fasho!”

steps.title: Mmhmm
steps.content: Mmhmm “Mmhmm” or other variations, like “mhm” or “mm-hmm,” are used to mean “yes.” Use “mmhmm” as an informal interjection that shows agreement for or acknowledgement of something another person said. Person 1: “She’s absolutely gorgeous.” Person 2: “Mmhmm. It’s almost not fair how pretty she is.”

steps.title: Aight
steps.content: Aight “Aight” (ah-ite) is a shortened form of the word “alright.” It’s often used similarly to “fasho,” to show agreement, approval, or confirmation. [3] X Research source Person 1: “Are you okay?” Person 2: “Yeah, I’m aight.”

steps.title: HY
steps.content: HY “HY” is an acronym of “hell yes.” [4] X Research source Use “HY” or “hell yes” to show that you strongly agree with or like something. Similarly, “HN” or “hell no” mean you strongly disagree with or dislike something. [5] X Research source Person 1: “Do you want to come to the party?” Person 2: “HY I’ll be there.”
